data.title: The Skilled Leader (film)
data.meta_description: The Skilled Leader is an 2021 Canadian-American live-action/animated biographical sports comedy film directed by Michael Dowse and written by Dennis Heaton. It is based on the book of the same name by Greg Appleton. The film follows Larry Jenkins (Larry the Cucumber) who got fired at the...
data.text:
The Skilled Leader is an 2021 Canadian-American live-action/animated biographical sports comedy film directed by Michael Dowse and written by Dennis Heaton. It is based on the book of the same name by Greg Appleton. The film follows Larry Jenkins (Larry the Cucumber) who got fired at the convenience store and gets the new job at a nearby high school as the director of his marching band, with Larry's son Ryan (Brett Dier), who dreams to be the best trumpet player.

Filming started in mid-May 2020 in London and Toronto before wrapping on late June 2020. The film was originally scheduled for a theatrical release on November 20, 2020, but was cancelled in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Instead, the film was digitally worldwide exclusively on Netflix on March 19, 2021. The next month, the director's cut version was released that includes extra scenes and the 11-minute fight scene.

The film received critical acclaim from critics, who praised the performances (particularly Cucumber and Dier), soundtrack, script, and humor. A sequel, titled The Skilled Leader 2, was released on October 1, 2021.

Summary[]

Larry Jenkins (Larry the Cucumber) works at the convenience store called Woodlands Store, which he had a great time. However, something went wrong, when he slaps a customer after wants to bring slushies, and got fired. After his assistant, Mr. Flakes (Zachary Bennett) claim Larry to get the new job at a nearby high school, he directed his marching band, while Larry's son Ryan (Brett Dier) dreams to be the best trumpet player. Can it will be the success, or it will get worst from disaster?

Plot[]

In 1991, in Ajax, Ontario, nine-year-old Larry Jenkins was bullied by his best friend Ray Law. Larry's father David tell Ray to stop bullying Larry, but Ray refuses. After a short fight, Larry's parents died from a fatal car crash, which causes Larry to be sad. Twelve years later, Larry moved to Arva, Ontario to get a job. Larry's boss, Tom Carter, gives Larry to work at the convenience store called Woodlands Store. Larry make a deal and start a career, with his son Ryan Jenkins (who also works at Woodlands Store). Three days later, Larry allegedly slaps a customer after a customer tells Larry to bring some slushies and Tom Carter fired Larry which makes Larry to quit his job.

At Larry's house, Larry collapsed after his heartbeat went too fast. Ryan called 911 and Larry was taken to the hospital, which makes Ryan to get on to Larry's car and starts follow the ambulance. At the hospital, the doctor named Dr. Change reveals that Larry has arrhythmia. Ryan asks Dr. Change that he will be better now, which Dr. Change agrees. After twelve minutes of work, Larry recovers and Ryan was happy to see Larry back home.

The next morning, Larry received a call from Tom Carter, telling Larry to get a new job at a nearby high school called Medway High School. Larry claim the deal, leaves his house, and drove off. When he arrived, he is confronted by Ray Law. He tells Larry about how they become best friends, but Larry was very angry and starts storms off. Meanwhile, Medway's High School principal Mr. Howard offers Larry to be the marching band director, which makes Larry so excited.

At music class, Larry teaches his students how to drum faster. Ryan practices and Larry was surprised about that. Outside at the track, Larry asks his students to train hard and be right, which his marching band starts playing afterwards. Later, Larry meets Ms. Davis, which conforms the rules of her classroom. Larry then enters her classroom, which asks her students to do the assignments. After feeling tired, Larry passes out and dreams about the students over rampage because of the last day of school. Larry suddenly wakes up and said to his students that he's feeling good. Later, Ray Law and his goons meets Mayor Gregor if he can capture Larry. Mayor Gregor was nervous about Ray's plan. Thrusted by a few students, Ray went to the track to see what's happened on. At BMO Field, during the Toronto FC game, Larry's marching band performs O Canada, which makes Larry so impressed. After the game, Larry ends up bumping into Mayor Gregor, who asks Larry to reply the email to his mother, but Larry was very furious and ends up throwing school supplies.

Later at the track, Larry wants his marching band to train smart. After practicing so hard, Larry and Ryan was taken by the consumers to prison. After Larry apologized for his actions, Ryan tells Larry that he wants to be the trumpet player, as Larry and Ryan got free from prison and starts running fast to go to Medway High School. At the presentation, Larry steps up and tells the students about his bad day yesterday, and the students starts cheering for Larry. During the football game, against the Strathroy Horses and the Medway Cowboys, Larry explains his marching band to be brave and smart. The game went to halftime show, when Larry's marching band is ready to play. As Larry's marching band plays two Michael Jackson songs, Larry meets Ray Law and Ray apologizes for his reckless behavior.

After the game, Larry gives Ryan the medal as the best trumpet player in the world. At the graduation ceremony, Mr. Howard tells the audience that Larry's marching band was the best performers in high school. After Larry talked about his marching band being great, Ryan steps up and gives Larry the trophy as the best coach. Afterwards, Larry re-joins at Woodlands Store and feels very happy to be back. In the mid-credits scene, Larry, Ryan, and the Medway students singing about they did it.

Cast[]

Larry the Cucumber as Larry Jenkins, who directs his marching band after losing his job at Woodlands store for allegedly slapping a customer.

Jaylen Harris voices Larry (1991), a younger version of Larry.

Brett Dier as Ryan Jenkins, Larry's son who plays his trumpet and dreams to be the best trumpet player.

Zachary Bennett as Mr. Flakes, Larry's assistant, who works at Medway High School.

Liam "Maker MJ" Atkinson as Ray Law, Larry's former bully and best friend. This is Atkinson's final role before his death on July 21, 2020; the film was dedicated to him.

Zack Atkinson (Liam "Maker MJ" Atkinson's son) plays Ray (1991), a younger version of Ray.

Ryan Gosling as Tom Carter, Larry's boss at Woodlands Store who gives information to Larry and fires him.

Amber Marshall as Sydney Jenkins, Larry's mother who died from a fatal car crash when Larry was 9 years old.

Ari Millen as David Jenkins, Larry's father who died from a fatal car crash when Larry was 9 years old.

Zack Lee as Thomas Chan, Larry's friend who plays basketball and other sports with Ryan.

David Sobolov as Mr. Jenney, a gym teacher. Mr. Jenney would be named after the Liam's High School Day character form the same name.

John Kapelos as Mayor Gregor, a mayor of Medway High School.

In addition, actress Nikki Roumel plays Alleged Customer, who asks Larry Jenkins to bring some slushies until Larry allegedly slaps her. Canadian singer Justin Bieber cameos as Medway Police Chief, a head police chief of Medway High School.

Production[]

Filming[]

Filming started on May 17, 2020 and ended on June 28, 2020.

Filming locations[]

Medway High School, Arva, Ontario (Medway High School)

Ardiel Electronics Ltd., Arva, Ontario (exterior shots of Woodlands Store)

Pinewood Toronto Studios, Toronto, Ontario (interior shots of Woodlands Store, Toronto Police Service and Dr. Change's room)

21584 County Rd 23, Arva, Ontario (Larry's house)

BMO Field, Toronto, Ontario (Toronto FC game)

7 Denny St, Ajax, Ontario (Larry's house in 1991)

Hong Shing Chinese Restaurant, Toronto, Ontario (during Larry's marching band's song)

Scotiabank Theatre Toronto, Toronto, Ontario (during Larry's marching band's song)

McDonald's, 470 Yonge St, Toronto, Ontario (during Larry's marching band's song)

Metropolitan Toronto Police Headquarters, Toronto, Ontario (exterior shots of Toronto Police Service)

St. Joseph's Hospital, London, Ontario (exterior shots of Dr. Change's room)

Pinewood Toronto Studios in Toronto, Ontario was initially going to used for interior shots at Larry's house, but got replaced by 21583 County Rd 23 in Arva, Ontario because the crew members won't be difficult to build the big house due to low budget costs and schedule changes. However, Pinewood Toronto Studios was used for the interior shots of Woodlands Store, Toronto Police Service and Dr. Change's room.

Reception[]

Critical response[]

On Rotten Tomatoes, the film holds an approval rating of 100% based on 87 reviews, with an average rating of 8.82/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "The Skilled Leader is a funny, bouncy and enjoyful movie that brings the music down for its fans." On Metacritic, the film has a weighted average score of 96 out of 100, based on 52 critics, indicating "universal acclaim". Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film an average grade of "A+" on an A+ to F scale.

Peter Debruge of Variety gave the film 4 out of 4 stars, saying, "The Skilled Leader was a fun and joyful movie which makes the audience so excited to see the music going on". Ty Burr of The Boston Globe also gave the film 4 out of 4 stars, praising the "inspired cast" and "sensitive jokes". Todd McCarthy of Deadline Hollywood gave the film a positive review, saying, "There's a lot of funny jokes, great music, and the amazing performance from Larry the Cucumber which the viewers can make you smile". John DeFore of The Hollywood Reporter gave a film 3 out of 4 stars, praising Dier's performance and music, calling it a "high-pack comedy".

Peter Travers of ABC News applauded the film, stating, "Great job man! This movie is the job well done!". Jessica Kiang of The New York Times praised the film for being "so hard-working work", and praised Larry the Cucumber's performance, calling him a "well-made star". Michael Phillips of The Chicago Tribune gave the film 3.5 out of 4 stars, calling it a "funny journey", and praised the cast and writing. Richard Roeper, also of The Chicago Sun-Times, gave the film 4 out of 4 stars, praising the performances, direction and humor.

David Ehrlich of IndieWire gave the film a grade of A+ and said, "With Larry the Cucumber put on the show, I like the whole movie that kids can enjoy." Aparita Bhandari of The Globe and Mail gave the film 4.5 out of 5 stars, writing: "I totally wanna love Larry the Cucumber because he's cheeky, he's funny, and he's amazing. Also, the stylish overhaul doesn't break up on the whole way, but more immersive, if you will, then make it right, because it was a whole beginning for him to get it going."
